title: Manny Takes on Upper Management
text:
Play the game here!
The game will be opened on a new page so you can come back and read more about how I made it at anytime.
I lead the development of this game with other UCLA students within a 15-week development period. This is a completed game with a complete storyline, 10 levels, 20 enemy types, and 50+ skills.

title: Manny Takes on Upper Management
text:
My role

Primary lead of the team of 10
Project management
System design
Level design (10 levels)
Enemy design (20 enemy types)
Implement features including

Hexagon-shaped tile map navigation (made an editor plug-in which can be found here)
Skill system and 50+ skills
Main combat mechanic – Power of Friendship!
Enemy AI
Dialogue tagging system
UI/UX (menus, skill selection interface)











hexagon-grid navigation







power of friendship









team member unlock menu





I have written up more about some aspects of the development (and product management) on this page. Feel free to check it out!

title: Oscar Su
text:
Hello! I’m Oscar. I like to ask questions, answer them, and use what I found to create cool tools and experiences. I do research, build tools to make others’ works easier, and design & program video games for my friends to play. For everything I create, I strive to make it fun, impactful, and memorable.
Check out my projects and games from the menu bar or get in touch with me through the platforms below!

title: Predicting Gender Pay Gap in Ireland
text: Using data from 1,945 Irish companies, I modeled how industry, bonus structures, and workforce composition influence gender pay gaps. The analysis identifies key drivers of wider disparities and shows a slight improvement across recent reporting years.

title: Predicting Gender Pay Gap in Ireland
text:
Goal
This project develops a predictive model to understand what drives gender pay gaps among large Irish companies following Ireland’s Gender Pay Gap Information Act (2022). Using a dataset of 1,945 company reports from PayGap.ie (2022–2024), we analyzed how factors such as industry, bonus structures, part-time pay gaps, and gender composition relate to differences in mean hourly pay.

title: Predicting Gender Pay Gap in Ireland
text:
What I did
In this project, I did the following:

Extracted 10 relevant predictors among 29 other correlated variables.
Compiled summary statistics for the 10 predictors + outcome variable
Visualized the distribution of all 11 variables
Performed best model selection through the following methods

Best subset selection
Forward selection
Backward selection


All three methods indicates that the full model is the best.

title: Predicting Gender Pay Gap in Ireland
text:
Results
Our final model shows the following factors affect the mean hourly pay gap between male and female in Ireland:

The year in which the data was collected
Mean gap in yearly bonus
Median gap in yearly bonus
Mean hourly part-time wage
Percentage of female employees that received a bonus
Percentage of female employees that received a benefit in kind
Percentage of female employees

Specifically, the mean gap in hourly wage between the two genders have decreased by .64% on average each year from 2022 to 2024.

title: Predicting Gender Pay Gap in Ireland
text:
Full Report
You can read the complete project report below. I have also attached the GitHub link to the project at the bottom of the page.

title: Games
text:
I started making games since the later-half of my sophomore year in college. I have now 8 games published on itch.io, and I’m still making more!
I focus on game design and feature implementation, so I always ask myself

How can I make [a complicated system/feature] work?
How can I make the game easily understood and fun?

title: Data Consulting for Savills Real Estate
Data Consulting for Savills Real Estate
text:
Goal
In 48 hours, we need to analyze a rich but messy data set provided by Savills Real Estate and present actionable insights to important stakeholders of the company.

title: Data Consulting for Savills Real Estate
text:
Results
Our team focused on advising the Real Estate company to invest in properties in emerging hub cities.
Specifically, for the financial sector, there is an emerging office hub in Orange County due to its proximity to airports and overall better quality of life compared to Los Angeles.
For the tech sector, there is an emerging office hub in San Jose due to the decreasing land lease space since COVID as well as improving living conditions compared to San Francisco.
In sum, we advised the company to focus on attracting finance companies to Orange County and tech companies to San Jose to meet the trend for maximum success.
Our creative insights and energetic presentation won us the Judge’s Choice Award out of 80 other competing teams.



Our presentation slides

title: Data Consulting for Savills Real Estate
text:
What I did

Data cleaning and Exploratory Data Analysis
GIS plotting of office locations on Google Map with Geopandas
Graphing amenity growth comparison between San Jose and San Francisco
Presenting our findings clearly and concisely to non-technical audience


You can read more about our project in this article written by UCLA.

title: Mutiny’s Last Reward
text:
Play the game here!
The game will be opened on a new page so you can come back and read more about how I made it at anytime.
Out of ~1500 entries, our game got 39th place in Fun (top 2%) and 97th Overall (top 7%)!
It was really fun making this game, and I’m really glad I have finally made it to within top 100 with my fourth LD attempt.

title: Mutiny’s Last Reward
text:
My role

Implemented all game features, including

Hook bounce physics
Trajectory calculation and preview
Dynamic + responsive multiplier text size
UI/UX (menus, buttons, pause page, etc.)

Gathered player feedback and improved game feel iteratively and rapidly










Trajectory Preview (pink dashed line)







Responsive Text Size (it gets bigger everytime you bounce)





You can also check out the Ludum Dare page and see what other players have said about our game!
